editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Melina Yeh

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: As it was acted, with great applause, by their majesty's servants at the private house in Drury lane.
London, printed for will: Sheares, at the bible in s. Paul's churchyard, near the little North door, 1654.

list.item: Valentia, daughter to the Mantuan Duke.

div.head: Act i. scene i.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Maturity and age have now at length
Imposed on me a careful providence
Both for my dukedom's safety, and the good
Of our most hopeful son prince Prospero.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: You grow to ripeness, and my thoughts are fixed
To have you troth-plight to some noble wife,
That in my aged years I may have comfort
In your fair issue, I would have you marry.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Marry my lord!

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Ay, marry Prospero.
I have laboured with a neighbour prince, possessed
of a fair daughter, to confirm a match
Betwixt thee and her, and 'tis concluded firmly;
Her name Valentia, she his only child,
By which a settled league grows 'twixt our dukedoms,
And thou by this art the true hopeful heir
Of both out rich and wealthy provinces:
Your answer.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: I am free, my lord, as th' uncurbed air,
That comes not within limit, as the light
That nothing can imprison. Shall I truly
Speak my own thoughts, and not dissemble with you?
I that am free 'mongst men, and uncaptived
To any, save the duty bound to you,
Am loath to make myself a woman's slave,
Briefly, my lord, I have no mind to marry.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Not marry boy? O, knew'st thou what a sweetness
And harmony's in love's blessed fellowship
Thou wouldst embrace it gladly; this blessed union,
This truelove's knot the gods themselves do tie,
And none but death dissolves. And what's virginity?
A something-nothing, singularity
Unsociable, so slightly reckoned of
That either sex, but to thy number grown,
Has a desire to leave it; be persuaded boy;
Thou hast beheld the picture, and it promises
A perfect lady; hadst thou seen the substance
Thou wouldst condemn the workman for so scanting
Her rare compareless beauty. Marriage,
Why 'tis an honour, emperors, Kings, and princes,
From the palace to the cottage held it sacred
And in a high religious reverence.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Well, my lord, I will be steered by you;
Even through the turbulent ocean of this life,
Where many dreadful tempests threaten us,
I shall be swayed by you, and entertain
This sweet captivity,

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Then art thou wise — the news. Flourish.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Ambassadors from Mantua crave admittance
touching affairs of state.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Admit 'em —Enter ambassadors.
Lords, your arrival is in happy season;
The marriage so long treated between the fathers
Shall by the children be confirmed at length,
'Tis now on foot.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Your grace mistakes the tenor,
And the strange purpose our embassy;
The prince our master let's know by us
That your alliance highly he disdains,
Contemns your love and near affinity,
And for just reasons, to himself best known,
Desires your opposition; for the marriage
Treated between you, esteems his daughter
Much undervalued, and not rated truly
To her best worth.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Pause lord ambassador,
So high hath thy words incensed our spleen,
And set so just an edge upon our wrath
That we want patience to bestow an care
Unto thy harsh conclusion: tell thy lord,
We did not so much overprize his love
As here his hate held in the basest scorn;
Nor can he so much undervalue us
As we his contracts and confederacy;
And for thy self-presumptuous Mantuan lord,
We favour thee to let thee undisgraced
Depart our court, be gone without reply,
Not Mantuans, but Mantua we defy.

sp.speaker: Ambassador
sp.l: Let me conclude my message.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Convey him hence;
Disdain our fellowship! Mantua shall know
His state shall lessen whilst our glories grow.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Ay, but, my lord, I hope the match is not broke off
Between me and the fair Valentia.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: O boy, didst thou but know what marriage were,
How full of troubles and contentions,
Thou wouldst forgo it gladly; who that's free
would be confined to base effeminacy?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: But that which hath made in me the deepest impression
Is the rare picture of the lady Valentia.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: The painter flattered her, in having her
Thou hast a painted mistress, of herself
The lady is mishapen and deformed.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Nay, take me with you, my lord,
I have beheld her picture, and it promises
A perfect lady; had I seen the substance
I should condemn the workman for so scanting
Her rare compareless beauty; these were your own words,
My lord, or I much misunderstood them.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: They were indeed, my lord, I am witness to them.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Well since your grace has no purpose to have me marry,
Shall I have your best furtherance to travel?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Yes, any thing to wear out the remembrance
Of Mantua's daughter.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Another boon, my lord.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: What's that coz?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: That I may be his partner in his travel, his associate
To bear him company, nothing else my lord.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Have your desires.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: I embrace your fellowship,
I'll travel, but whither? to have a sight of the fair Valentia,
There shall be the period of my voyage;
What though her father and mine be opposites, she and I
May happily agree well enough when we meet together.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: My lord, what limit shall we have to play the wandering knights in? Or how long shall it be ere we set forward on our journey? We were best go well provided, for we must see Spain, France, and England ere we return.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Some ten days hence you shall set forward,
Your stay hath a year's limit.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Then come, fair coz, we must provide ourselves;
Her picture's lovely, and it much contents,
And I must see the face that it presents. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Your youths cannot outstrip my gravity,
I have you boys, and aim at your intents;
this cunning suit for travel is a colour
To some close practice to deceive my age,
But I shall wind them both, Cosmo.

sp.speaker: Cos.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: The manage of our state we leave to thee,
Whom we know wise and gravely provident;
Our purpose is to chase these travellers,
Whose voyage we mistrust.

sp.speaker: Coz
sp.l: 'Tis dangerous
Unto your noble person, full of hazard
And doubtful peril.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: I am confident,
Dissuade me not, for my intent is fixed;
In some suspectless shape I'll after them,
And sound the inmost of their thoughts, yet pass unknown;
Cosmo regard your charge whilst I provide. Flourish.
To find that craft they with such cunning hide. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: You have breathed defiance then.

sp.speaker: Ambassador
sp.l: I have my lord.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: And how did he receive it?

sp.speaker: Ambassador
sp.l: With such scorn
And proud contempt, that with far greater spleen
He threatened us than we could menace him.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: No matter, this late difference pleaseth us,
You have demeaned yourself even to our wish,
Now leave us to our private meditations. Exeunt. Em.
Come hither sirrah, I repose in thee
Much trust and much assured confidence,
I have brought thee up of a youth boy, I have.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: You have if it shall please your grace.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Thy father was a good old servitor,
I loved him well, I did, indeed I did,
Believe it, for I did so.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: I believe your lordship without swearing.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Thou knowest my daughter should have been affied
unto Verona's son prince Prospero,
I know thou knowest it.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: I have had, if it please your grace, such an inkling,

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: But a difference since
Hath fallen betwixt us, nay, in such a manner
That by our leaguers we have threatened war,
And war is like to ensue to come to thee.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: If it shall please your honour, I'll save you that labour and come to you.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Conceive me, I will come to that concerns thee,
Thou knowest how dear I affect my daughter,
Ay, and how dear I affect my gold,
Speak, did I ever yet part with one piece
To guerdon thee, a sign I loved it well.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: No, never, if it shall please your honour, I'll do you right in that, you ever loved me too well to give me any thing, I have ever heard you reported for as covetous and niggardly a noble gentleman as ever bore sway here, you are one of the most closefisted carpenters that ever bare rule in Mantua.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: To keep my daughter that she marry not,
By which I like wise may reserve her dower,
I have devised this opposition
'T ween Valentia and prince Prospero;
More suitors are now resident in court,
But to prevent them I'll devise a tower
In which to shut my daughter so impregnable
And full of doors, of which I'll keep the keys,
That she in vain shall strive to issue out,
Or they to enter in; this strong foundation
Is laid already, workmen are employed,
And all things promise prosperous success;
In this employment thou shalt have a charge,
An overseers place, because I know thee
Simple but sure of faith: we i trust thy reach,
As far from craft as cunning, truly honest
Because not over wise.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p:
I must entreat your lordship I may have a pair of chopines, or some high corked shoes, or else I shall never
play the overseer well; or if your lordship will allow me but a ladder, I warrant you I will oversee your workmen.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: No more, there shall be order from our treasury
To furnish this rich building —

div.stage: Enter Florence, Ferrara, Julio, Valentia, and Duchess.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Our welcome would show better,
If we could hear it from the ladies.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: They come well that speed well, if we could find ourselves well sped, than we should not doubt to presume we were welcome.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Lord Julio, are the toils prepared and set for our appointed game. ?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: They are my lord.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Then princes we devote this day to pastime
And chasing of the stag, these beauteous ladies,
That must this day take leave of liberty,
Shall in our sport associate us; Valentia,
And you most beauteous, and my dearest love,
I here protest myself your guardian,
Hoping to see you, ere two months expire,
The Mantuan Duchess.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: I hope no such matter; but my lord,
Am I your dear, as you proclaim me?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: My dearest dear.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Then being in the chase I shall fear in the hunting:
To come near you.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Your reason sweet.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Lest being your dear you should strike me.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Still is this lady cross to my designs,
But time may work her; daughter, mount your steed,
And lords to horse ▪ the morning grows upon us,
And steals towards midst of day.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: We but attend
Your highness' company.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Lady, this day I will not start from your side.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You'll be worse to me than a stitch then.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Nor will I leave you lady,

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: And yet you shall have free leave to leave me when you please.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: We trifle hours, found out your bugles sh
And the thick air with pleasing echoes fill. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: To ring thy knell, for this day thou art doomed
To perish by the hand of Julio —Horns.
The Mantuan prince
Is now upon the chase, I hear the cry,
But ere the stag fall the proud Duke must die. Exit.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Hark what a shrill applause doth welcome us
Unto the Mantuan confines.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: It seems the Duke or some of his train
Are in the forest chasing some game;
Nay, it must needs be so of necessity, they would not else make
This noise unless they were all horn-mad.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: If I should come a-wooing , noble coz,
I should presage the music of these horns
Might, to my future match, prove ominous;
But now let's mix ourselves amid the train,
And see what fair adventure may befall us.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Sever ourselves, it may be that sweet face
Your father praised may meet us in the chase.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: I like well this division, come let's part,
And let's be henceforth strangers, thus conditioned,
The first that can prefer himself, or service
Unto the Duke, or gain his sovereign grace
Shall for his friend provide some eminent place.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I am pleased my lord, then come let's mount away,
The morning's old, and we shall lose much day. Exeunt. (Horns.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: With these Italian tricks villains oft mask
Their grim bloodthirsty fronts, and when they purpose
To act some horrid murder, if prevented,
Thus pass unknown, these bought I of a Jew,
A fellow that professeth villain;
I'll dog the Duke, whom if I can but single,
Or light on from his train, but thus, 'tis done,
The dukedom seized, and fair Valentia won;
Auspicious hell I thank: thee, thou art still
True to black deeds, and friend to such as kill —

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: My horse hath failed me, and I forced on foot
To lag behind, my train have left me all,
Led by the music of so fair a cry,

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: To find a place where thou mayest fitly die.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Who named death to me?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: One whose powerful hand ▪
Shall guide thy dukedom, daughter, and thy land,
And at one blow gain all —

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: And we so nigh,
The slave that threatened death himself shall die.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Prevented. Exit.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Courage, my lord, the traitorous groom is fled,
And you ingirt with safety.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Noble stranger,
The life thou hast given me shall be ever thine,
And thank the stars that brought thee to my rescue,
They owed thee a great fortune, thou hast saved
The Mantuan Duke from death.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Are you my lord,
The noble Mantuan prince? what traitors hand
Durst threat your life?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I know not, gentle sir,
But for yourself thus much presume from me,
You shall be ever ours, to none more dear,
By whom I am freed from treason, death and fear.

div.stage: Enter July, florende, Ferrara, Valentia, Duchess, and Montecelso.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: This way, my lords, I saw the Duke in perils
An ugly slave, his face much vizard-like.
Assailed the Duke, and with his weapon drawn
Fled through the forest, I pursued the traitor
Whilst I had breath, but fears and guilt of conscience
Gave his speed wings; but see my lord's in safety,
Whose welfare I salute thus on my knee,
Glad in my soul that he from death is free.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My father threatened I blessed be that fair hand
That wrought his safety.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Thank this gentleman,
This noble youth, 'tis he by whom I live,
Never so near my death, never so near it,
So mortal men are still when least they fear it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O do but tell me, thrice renowned sir,
How I may show me thankful to your love,
Whose noble hand preserved my father's life.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Madam, your grace, your favour and good thoughts
Are gifts above my merit.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Stranger, thou hast won the opinion and suffrage of the whole court, and bound the prince of Florence to be thy grateful debtor.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: We made haste
To the Duke's rescue, but it was thy fate
Our valours to prevent, we came too late.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: Yet did lord Julio, with what speed he might, haste us to this great danger.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: 'Twas my duty
And service to my lord, whom thus to see
Secured from death glads, almost franticks me;
Legs for my life I thank, and thou my brain
For making up this broken flaw again.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: We thank you Julio, chiefly you fair stranger,
Whom for your service we will raise in court,
And breast next our most dear Valentia;
But she is for the tower barred with twelve doors,
And this the last day of her liberty,
That's our next business; once more welcome sir,
Attend on us to court, our happy fate
Hath given me safety, and advanced thy state. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: O fair Valentia!

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: My lord, if you had been born less than a prince, yet you have wrought yourself into grace.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Here set a period to our travels, make a full point here.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: And that, my lord, is the full end of a sentence; but shall we give over travel till we have seen something worth seeing.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Worth seeing sayest thou? what's Valentia?
Travel from pole to pole, stand at the centre
And progress round about the spacious signs,
Or, were it possible, sit with the sun
In his high noon ▪ tide glory, and from thence
Survey the kingdoms of this lower world,
Thou canst not find her match, Apollo's hair
Is dull to hers, her fingers, hand, eye, front.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Take me with you my lord: this marvellous thing you call her beauty, is it ought but ordinary flesh and blood? Are those gold wiry hairs with which Apollo might go string his harp, are they ought but the plain hairs of her head? Her ivory palm, that doth in touching melt, embroidered with blue arteries, is it ought but a lady's hand and fingers? And this strange thing, this wonder of the world, whose peer cannot be found between the poles, are not all these nine wonders in one, she that was here even now, the Duke's daughter Valentia?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: O my dear Montecelso, this I know,
But such an admiration hath surprised
The freedom of my senses, that it robs me
Of my true judgement.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Be advised by me ▪ you love this lady, but so strict is like to be her imprisonment, that you may as easily pass by the gates that Cerberus keeps, as through the doors of this castle; you are already in favour with the Duke, do but prefer me to be overseer of the work, if I do not ▪ work it so that I will bring you to oversee her, turn me out of my office as one not worthy the name of an architecture.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p:
I shall commend thee for a man well skilled a such great structures, it may be the Duke
may trust me on my word.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: And if I do not make him dote as much on you for your valour, as you make him enamoured on me for my skill in building, may this tower turn to the tower of Babel, and make a second confusion between us, there remains for you nothing but this, to win the favour of the lady; and for your access to her, if I do not teach you to counterfeit all the Duke's keys, turn by all the wards of his locks and lay open all the jury of his twelve doors that he hath paneled against your entrance, report me to be no man of my trade ▪ away my lord ▪ leave this melancholy, walk by her window ▪ and cast sheeps eyes that way towards her chamber, let me alone to stand sentinel and watch if the Duke come ▪Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter clown, a smith, a mason ▪ a bricklayer, a carpenter.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Come on my masters, the Duke has appointed me to be overseer of his works, the building of this tower is put to my indiscretion; therefore come every one of you, and from me take your directions; what are you?

sp.speaker: Magician
sp.l: I am a free mason, and expert in squaring stone.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: A good proper square fellow, if your trade be in stone,
I make no question but you will work hard.

sp.speaker: Magician
sp.p: I warrant you sir I'll do my endeavour; will you give us directions?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: First you must make a fair large post at the entry.

sp.speaker: Magician
sp.p: I warrant you I'll make a large porch that any lady shall go in and out at pleasure.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: To see how you mistake; you must make it that nobody can go in and out at pleasure but only my lady, it must be too wide for any that's less than she, and too straight for any that's greater than she, you conceive me.
sp.l: O sir, 'tis not possible.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p:
Tell not me of possible, such directions I had, and such an one I must have made ▪ then must I have fair bay windows that must always stand open and give no light, that they that stand without and look in may see nobody within, and she that stands within and looks out may see nobody without ▪ the
reason is, my lord means to keep his daughter in that tower, where she must neither see nor be seen.

sp.speaker: Magician
sp.p: Then none must offer to look out from the inside, nor in from the outside, else 'tis not within the compass of workmanship.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Tell not me of workmanship, such windows I must have made: now carpenter for you, you must make the doors of that fashion that women may go in but men may not, and they must be of such wood as will not let a lover come near it, for my lord will have no lovers come near his castle.

sp.speaker: Carpenter
sp.p: Then you must have somebody to keep them out; here are wise directions!

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: For you goodman padlock, you must hammer out your locks and keys with such art, that if the Duke, or any from him, offer to open, the key may turn at pleasure, but if any lover or suspicious person come to enter, nonsum, non possum, non licet esse domi.

sp.speaker: Smith
sp.p: That's as much as to say, they must have no entrance there.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Smith, you have hit the nail on the head; what's your place?

sp.speaker: Brick.
sp.p: I have the charge of the brickwork, and must build the chimneys if you would give me directions.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Marry will I sir, you must have a special regard in your chimneys that they cast heat, though there be no fire in them, and the kitchen chimney especially must every meal yield roast meat without sending to market, and so to work for a spurt, and after merrily to dinner.

sp.speaker: Omues.
sp.l: A good motion. Exeunt.

div.head: Act ii. scene i.
div.stage: Enter Mantua, Florence, Ferrara, Julio, and Prospero.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Have you given charge, lord Julio, that my Duchess
Be nobly served as her whom Mantua loves?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I have my lord.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: And that Valentia be enclosed and shut
From all her suitors eyes.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I gave such order.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Enough now my lords.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: You give us fair words; but keep us from the sight of the fair ladies.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Soft and fair, soft and fair.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: We know they are both soft and fair, and that's the reason we desire so much both to see and feel them.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I would beneath the ground sells of this castle,
By miners craft, were placed some strong petards,
To which I would give fire and blow this structure
Up into air that prisons thus my love;
But Julio peace, and some advantage wait
To show to her thy love, to him thy hate.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: My lord, I can compare you to none so rightly as to the King Aerifius, that shut up his daughter Danae in a brazen tower, but you know the end of it, there was a Jupiter that with a golden picklock broke through those brazen gates, and made the maid a mother. Now if
sp.l: I were to choose a godhead, of all the gods that are
Would I, for her sake, wish to be a Jupiter.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: For men to be made gods it were a wonder,
You Jove, and neither have his power nor thunder?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Shall I bail her my lord? I'll put you in good security.

sp.speaker: Magician
sp.l: But not in better security than I have put her in already,
Yet better would do well; o for a man
skilful in architecture, and composing
Strong frames and forms of building.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: Now's my question;
My lord, there is a stranger in your court
Whose outside though it promise not much art,
Yet is he so ingenious, and so apt,
Of such opinion and direction too,
That could you win him to be so employed,
As we shall hardly, for men excellent
Are curious of their skill, you cannot find
A man to match his skill in Italy.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Thou wert I see, fair knight, marked in thy cradle
To do me all good offices, bring that man
To my employment, I will guerdon him
With more than he can ask.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Ay, but my lord,
He is a man always so absolute,
And stands so much upon his excellence
In fine contriving and rare edifices
We shall have much ado to win him to't —Ent. Mont.
Here comes the man.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Sir, your due praise hath, like a harbinger,
Gone all the way before you to provide you
A place in my regard, you are most welcome,
You have not seen my castle?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Yes my lord, I have perused it.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: What think you of the work?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: 'Tis pretty, pretty;
'Tis well for modern bvilders, homebred workmen,
'Twill serve: yet let me tell you, worthy lord,
They never looked on high Mauselus' tomb,
Never beheld a Grecian pyramis,
Rich Crassus' house at Rome, Diana's temple
At Ephesus, nor the grand city Caire,
'Tis well for them that are no travellers;
Saw you me draw a form, or a fine model,
The fabric greatly would enamour you,
But yet 'tis well enough, pretty, not famous ▪

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Shall I entreat you to direct my workmen,
And I will weigh your pains down with reward.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Your tower as 'tis, my lord, will serve the turn,
Is finely seated, and to keep your daughter
Close from the eyes of strangers, well contrived,
Yet could I by a plot, but why should I
Engage me in such work? 'tis well already,
Well, very well.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: You can contrive it better, noble stranger;
Make trial of my bounty, by mine honour
It shall not fail your hopes.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Did not I tell you at the first, my lord,
He would be wondrous dainty of his cunning?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: So most men are in things they best excel;
Shall I prevail fair sir?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Well, I am won
To end that frame your workmen have begun;
I have perused the situation,
Find it secure and full of able trust,
Yet one defect I find: could you pick out
Some noble knight, whose valour did exceed,
To build for him a lodging near that tower
Where fair Valentia is to live enclosed,
He, as a guardian, or a sentinel,
Might keep continual watch, defend the passage,
And keep the place strong and impregnable?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Where should I find a man worthy that place,
Whose valour might supply this my employment?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Let me engage my person to that business.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Accept of me my lord, I'll be her guardian.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Let the Ferrara marquess be employed
In this adventure.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: List to me my lord:
'Mongst other quests, once as I travelled Greece,
There, at the sack of a most famous town,
I saw a knight, now resident in court,
Do such high deeds of arms, that living Hector,
Had he survived to see his chivalry,
would from the worthies nine have raised his name,
To have eternised him with golden fame.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: In our court resident?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Yes, that strange knight,
What wonders have I seen him do in fight!
Would he attempt it, all the plot were sure,
Yourself, your daughter, and your tower secure;
But you shall hardly win him to attempt.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: That he is valiant I must needs confess
To my life's safeguard I have proved no less;
O every way my friend; renowned soldier,
Pardon me that I have not done you honours
Worthy your high deserts.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Alas my lord.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: My cares are deaf unto excuse, and shut
'Gainst all denial.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I am exceeding loath.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I shall deserve it, noble gentleman,
I must not be denied, this skilful stranger
Shall cause my workmen build you a fair lodging
Next to the castle, and adjoining close
Unto my daughter's chamber: this is all;
Can you deny me this?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Your former honours
Bestowed so largely on my mean deserts
Have been with me prevailing orators
Upon your part, and I at length agree
This skilful artist shall dispose of me.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Again prevented.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: On all sides happy, fortunate, and blessed,
Now my disturbed thoughts attain true rest,
Only one bar unto my best desires
Is the entire affection and true zeal
I bear the beauteous Duchess.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: O my lord,
You have entertained the most affecting wooer
In Europe, or the world, therein he's better
Than in his architecture, he's but young,
yet Tully never had such a fluent tongue.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Hemmed in with all felicities about,
Having these helps what need I now misdoubt?
You shall sir bear from me most kind commends.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Who, I my lord? Alas.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Come sir, you shall
Unto the beauteous Duchess whom I love.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: You do not know my weakness.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: You are strong
In your acute words, and praised for your sweet tongue,
A token I will send by you, that give her,
And in your own sweet words my love deliver.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: If need's I'll do't my lord: upon my life
The provident Duke has found me out a wife.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Follow us lords, I am full of jocund mirth,
My fears are dead, my joys receive new birth. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Now prince, was not this wrought out of adamant?

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: But what's the mark that all the several arrows shoot at?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: This is the mark ▪ mark it, I am made chief overseer of the work, and your lodging is directly against the chamber of the lady: now will I appoint a private door to be made through the wall, by and through which you may have access, ingress and regress at your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Thou hast builded in my heart a tower already
Of steady and firm hope.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Take my word I am excellent at architecture.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: But touching thy employment with the Duchess,
Art thou so mad to woo her for the Duke?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Yes, I will set him out in his lively colours, deal you as soundly with the maid as I will work with the widow, and I doubt not but we shall both live to be in the belief there are no cuckolds but bachelors, our stay is suspicious, be it your charge to hire —
sp.l: A workman to make the private door through the wall,
And leave it to my wit to cover all.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: That be my care ▪
Thou wooest a widow, but I court a maid,
the way thou treadest is easy, broad, and free,
But mine is straight, and danger ushers me. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: No marvel though Jove often went disguised,
And in his rural habit traced the earth
To hear and see th' affairs of mortal men.
I being a prince have in these lowly weeds
Seen more than being resident in court;
But I am now in Mantua, and thus far
I have pursued my son by common tract;
The Duke and I are dangerously opposed,
And therefore this disguise must shelter me;
The Mantuan court I'll now search ere I go
For Montecelso and my princely son —

div.stage: Enter clown with a rule and line.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Let me see, let me see, make a door so broad, ay, so broad, and thus wide; now unless I had the lady here to take measure of her 'tis impossible that ever I should make the door fit ▪ if a man take a thing in hand, it is for his credit to do it workman like; now if I should make the door too straight to pinch her body, or too wide to sit upon her like a sack, what credit should I have by my workmanship?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Heaven save you sir.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Et tu quoque my friend; let me see, let me see, now have I forgotten whether the door must be made for her to come thus, with her arms broad ways, pilcher-fashion, and a kembo; or thus sideways, like a shotten herring.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Sir, without interruption to your business, shall I entreat a few words with you.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Hold here, hold here a little, thus high, ay, thus high, just thus high; but now my friend, if I should make it just thus high according to my measure, and then the party being yet but young should grow higher, there were all the labour cast away ▪ come, come, I must have a new measure.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Sir, what means this? I understand it not ▪
Pray let me ask you but one question.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p:
Hold again, hold again, say my friend I make it of this breadth according to my measure, just to a hair; very good my
friend, but now the party being yet but lean that it should be made for, say the party hereafter grow fat, or as the fox that when his belly was empty crept through a small hole into a hen-roost, and there filled his belly so full, that when he should come out again, there was no room; colon was grown so great, and so poor Reynald was taken in the manner, no, my friend, this must not be.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: I pray sir to what end take you this measure?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Why, my friend, because I would do nothing out of measure, I hope you have not played the old eavesdropper .

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: No sir, but if your chief affairs be ended,
Let me discourse with you.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: My friend, as you have lent a hand to my line, so will I lend an care to your tale.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: What's the best news in court?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Troth sir nothing but this, that the prince is magnanimous, the courtiers egregious, the ladies beauteous, the place conspicuous, and the building in hand most sumptuous.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: What strangers so journey there, what men of note?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Troth sir there are only two, one is most brave at models and buildings, and hath undertaken a most brave piece of work.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: That's not my son, he never studied that,
No, not his friend.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: But there is another, the finest sweet-faced gentleman, that saved the Duke's life in the forest, if you know not that you know nothing, if you know not him you know nobody .

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: What manner of man is he?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: A most dainty man, much of my size, he hath a most leering lip and tempting eye, there is only this difference between us, for you would take us to be brothers, but that he has more hair than I, and I more wit than he; father, you are not worthy to be held a good subject, if you love not him that had like to have killed him that would have killed the Duke, he hath set me about this piece of work here, let me see, this blockhead of mine will never bring it to any purpose — ent. Prosp. O here comes the gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: He interpose himself and save the Duke ▪
that look, that face, that gesture is my sons.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: O well encountered, tell me honest fellow,
Hast thou dispatched the close and secret door?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Not yet my lord.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: What dost thou with that line?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: I am staying here, that if she should come down this way,
I may take measure of her to make the door fit for her body.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Away you ass, thou wilt betray my purpose;
But sirrah on your life use seeresie,
And with all speed dispatch it; but what's he?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: A fellow that wonders so young a gentleman as yourself should take the Duke's quarrel in hand, and save him from the sword of a traitor.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: 'Tis Prospero my son, shape, gate, and voice,
To hear his valour praised how I rejoice,

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: This fellow at a blush looks like my father,
Such settled gravity lives in his eye;
Nor is there wanting ought save power and state,
Attended with the royal name of Duke
To make him the same man; but I digress;
Come to your private task, sirrah be secret,
Or thy life pays for't.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: I warrant you sir, I would be as loath to hazard my neck as you the Duke's favour, his favour once lost may be got again, but my neck once broke, I'll not trust all the bone-setters in Mantua to have it new set; fear not me.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: This aged man is still tossed in my thoughts,
And ever as I cast a look on him,
His face grows more familiar with my eye;
But to our task in hand, why do we stay?
His cloth of state cannot be turned to grey. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Is this your travel son? O heaven to see
The follies and the vain delights of youth,
How headstrong, and how full of violence!
Why should he take this way? why sojourn here
Within my enemy's court? If to revenge
My injuries, why did he rescue him?
O mine own boy!
I must commend thee yet that couldst win love
Even of thy enemies, and honoured fame
'Mongst those, that if they knew thee, hate thy name;
I'll listen further till some fate bewray
The full intent of his enforced stay. Exit.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: My daughter is securely closed and shut
In my new turret, and the noble knight,
As her bold guardian, hath his place assigned,
Those fears have end; now to my suit in hand,
The stranger whom so late I entertained
Is my solicitor, and is directed
To meet and court the Duchess in the garden,
Where from this place I may behold their gestures,
The manner of his courtship and conceit:
How is my heart disturbed between hope and fear —
Comfort cold spirit, they now methinks appear.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: The greatest instance of my love is, that I have given into your hands my liberty and life; my name is Montecelso, and that noble gentleman that rescued the Duke prince Prospero, son to the Duke of Verona, it lies in you either to save me alone, or to destroy us both; give me no denial, sweet lady, rather kill me than disclose me to the Duke, so shall you lessen the supposition of your cruelty.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: In that you are a stranger, I can no less in courtesy, nor more in modesty than to say you are welcome, though I have been trusted by many, I never betrayed any; I could call you rash to trust so rich a jewel as your life unto the breast of a woman, but though you be so overbold to presume upon me, I will not prove so over cruel to tyrannize over you.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: She talked a great long tale, and loud she spoke,
sp.l: To her again, do not that answer take.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Madam, by all the honours of a gentleman, my love is as pure to you, and as free from blemish as is the element of fire, or the white robe of innocence.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I know it is, I know it is.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p:
All the comfort I can give you is this, the life you
have committed to me shall be kept for you, the love you have proffered to me I will ponder on, I will never marry till you are bestowed, nor ever assume the name of wife till you meet with a lady to call you husband.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Give me your hand of that.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: I may well trust you with my hand that have trusted me with your heart.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: A match I hope, for see, they now join hands,
My heart for joy upon the tiptoe stands;
Follow it now, strike whilst the iron's hot,
I never was pleased till now with a fine plot.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: But you forget in all this to speak for the Duke.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Madam, 'tis true, I did forget myself, I must entreat you to think of him, but I do not entreat you to think well of him, as ill as you can possible; I beseech you love to be out of his sight in any case, and to love him best when he is farthest off: I would have you in all humility to honour him, but I would not for a world have you to marry him; have I yet spoke for him sufficiently?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Good, good, well spoken, and well acted too,
He is not half so good to plot as woo.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: My lord, the love we now celebrate betwixt ourselves should once have been solemnised between our parents, before these odds grew between the two Dukes.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Though the Dukes be at odds, let us make even,
Contracts are made on earth, but sealed in heaven;
Madam, let the Duke's love be the colour to our meeting: I must go tell him the manner, for with much longing he expects my return.
Once more let these our hands our hearts make sure,
So thrive I as my love is chaste and pure. Exit.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Again, again, fair fortune be thy speed,
Once more join hands, and then 'tis done indeed;
I knew the good knight would not choose a man
That should not fit my purpose, heaven I pray.
His place may take effect the other way,
And his intents as prosperously proceed;
But I must hence to meet him with all speed. Exit.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You wrong mine honour, and I shall complain,
I charge you get you back the way you came.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Banish the heaven if you exile me hence;
My deed, though it seem rash, yet is begotten
In as pure birth as truth, and as upright
As is the scale of justice; I am free
From all mis-thoughts, then do not banish me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What are you sir? whence are you? what's your name?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I am your friend, should you desire to know
What my name is, alas my name's your foe.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Being my friend, and court me in this kind
You should have come and left your name behind.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I should indeed, my name is Prospero.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Prince Prospero, and the Duke Verona's son, our professed foe?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Give me some other name,
Call me your friend and I am not the same.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You're not the same, you are th' adventurous knight
That from the forest-treason saved my father.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I was prince Prospero when I reasoned him,
And so continued till I saw your face;
But as my heart within your eye was tossed,
At once my hatred and my name I lost.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: It was a kind foes part to save a foe.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: That kind foe's part performed prince Prospero

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Such a fair foe that no more hurt intends
I should prefer before a many friends.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Lady, we should have been espoused together,
But that our fathers differed in the dower;
Shall gold divorce them whom the soul of love
Links in an endless knot? I for your love
First hazarded my life to come disguised
Only to view your face, next I contrived
This private passage, known to none but us;
If this deserve no love, no friendly grace,
Confine my life if banish me this place.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: If nothing but the rescue of my father
should plead in your behalf; it deserved favour;
But when your travel, and your servant love,
Attended with year feature and rare parts,
Your studious means to compass my consent
And hazard of your fortunes many ways,
When all these plead together forcibly
They draw me in a treble folded chain
Your zealous love to pay with love again.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I left my name behind me at Verona,
And now no more prince Prospero but your love;
Wear this for me, and use in these affairs
My art, fear not, I will devise a means
To win your fathers grant unto this match.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: So we, my lord, shall doubly be made friends,
I take it as an earnest of your love,
And hope of my release from this strict bondage;
Accept of me in interchange this ring,
My father gave it me, keep't from his eye,
Or he will end our loves by jealousy —

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: As I have been, I will be firm and sure,
Long may the date of our chaste love endure —

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I prithee, sweet marquess, since my success is so bad with the Duchess let's walk by the Duke's new edifice, and see if we can take a view of the young enclosed lady.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Content my lord, the Duke's strictness adds but spurs to my desire; for commonly what we are most forbid that still we most covet.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Then should you with some engine raze these walls
That interdicts your passage to that tower;
Had I such power I should enjoy such thoughts,
But Julio is a subject.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Now you put me in mind of such generous and noble thoughts, let's take a view of the castle, and spy where it is weakest, that there, if hereafter we should invade, we may give the best and safest assault.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
Now you speak like a politics lover, come let's take a view of the building: but see, see, do you know him that's
talking with the Princess Valentia?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Is't possible, I'll in and tell the Duke.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Nay, leave me not behind, I'll second you.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Introth lad art good at that? you are a notable rascal, can you come to't
So closely? is this your courage my courageous knight?
I'll see how Mantua applauds this fight. Exit.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: We are descried my lord, then post away,
Get through the private door.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Fear not sweet lady, I'll so blind their eyes,
That we will still live free from their surprise. Exit.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ten thousand times adieu, I am full of fear;
Where love inhabits danger still draws near. Ex.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: All is too good to be true, but tell me,
And answer every word upon thy oath.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Upon my oath I will.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Then tell me, tell me,
Didst thou with all thy best prevailing words,
With all thy art, with all thy eloquence
Urge her to love? speak that upon thy oath.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Upon my oath I did entreat her love:
With all my art, with all my eloquence.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: And did she grant thy suit?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: She did my lord.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Thou honest man, thrice happy be the hour
That I first met thee; now upon thy life
Tell me how speedest thou?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Well upon my life.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: And will she love?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: She will.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Thou hast her promise

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I have my lord.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: But hast thou, as thou art a gentleman

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: As I am a gentleman I have my lord,
I should be sorry else.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Did thy word prosper, took thy suit effect ▪
Will she be won to marry at thy motion?
And did she give her hand unto the bargain.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: My suit and words were both effectual,
She's won to marry, and I have her hand
As witness to the bargain.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Friend, swear that.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Upon my life, my lord, it is most true.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: 'Tis well, I thank my stars.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I thank my stars too.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I thank thee too, but for thy industry
This thing had never chanced.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Nay, that's most certain,
Had I not took my time and plied it thoroughly,
I had never won her heart.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: But thou hast won it.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Ay, I thank heaven my lord.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: And I thank heaven my lord.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: She hath passed her word and her firm promise to me.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: It glads me at the heart, the very heart.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Nor have I reason to be sorry for it.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Once more I thank thee friend.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: 'Tis not so much worth my lord.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: That be my peril, I'll 'Bide the venture.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: You are like to do that howsoever.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: There's gold, gramercy friend, I am thy debtor;
This is but th' earnest of those rich rewards
Thou shalt receive from me.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I thank your grace,
And I protest I would not for a million
My labours had been fruitless, trust upon it,
The greatest aim of all my suit is won,
Her heart, her hand, her free consent is won
to match with me.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I thank my fate 'tis so;
But now about my other business friend,
To look unto my works; blessed be the hour
I met thee first, but all is in heaven's power. Exit Mon.
An honest and a faithful gentleman
Upon my warrant, and I dare rely
Upon his trust and certain honesty —

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: My lord, you are wronged.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Disparaged.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: And disgraced.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I bring thee news, thy castle is surprised,

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Thy fort is taken.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: And your daughter seized.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: How may that be lords? 'tis not possible.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I speak no more, my lord, than what I saw.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: What I beheld.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: And what these eyes have seen.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: That stranger knight, in whom thou most affiest.
I saw in a bay window court thy daughter.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Embrace her in his arms, and elapse her waste.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: She darting smiles at him, and the other.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Nor did they blush, change face, or cease their courtship, but stood as at the gaze.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: July, and lords,
You make me smile; have you so late perused
The situation, and observed the passages,
And can you judge wit or the art of man
Can force access there and not use my keys?
Tush, you deceive yourselves —Enter Prospero.
Ha ha, ha, come hither knight and laugh with me
At their three follies, they would needs persuade me
They saw thee court my daughter in her chamber,
Where thou didst publicly discourse thy fill,
And yet these keys here at my girdle still.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: They did me the more wrong; I scale your tower ▪
It lies not in the reach of humane power.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I know it well, tush, while these 〈◊〉 hang here
Were she fair Danae I not Jove would fear.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: You tower is stronger the Aerifius hold.
Besides, I am not Jove to rain down gold.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Is't possible my eyes should deceive me!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Sure 'twas he, or the devil in's likeness.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: There's in this some witchcraft.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: You might as well say that you see this hand
Reaching as high as unto yonder clouds.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I should have seen that ring upon that hand
Once in my daughter's chamber; o my heart
Why dost thou make such traffic with pale fear?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: He hath spied the gift, and knows the ring I wear.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: The same, the same, I will in and see
The issue of my fears, twelve locks, twelve keys,
And every door too double-barred with iron,
She in the inmost room walled round about,
It cannot be, and yet the ring I saw
Urgeth my fears, and forceth me withdraw. Exit.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I know your, 〈◊〉 and must your speed prevent,
But I delay; 'tis high time I were gone,
Twelve doors the Duke must pass, and I but one. Exit.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Shall I not trust my eyes?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Though mine should fail me I would witness yours.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: It makes me passed my thoughts.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: There's some strange juggling could we find it out;
In all his acts your stranger let us trace,
And if we can, work him some deep disgrace. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What hast thou done Valentia, given thy heart
Unto a stranger, and thy father's foe?
I wrong the prince, who with a heart entire
Pursues my spousal love with chaste desire;
This match successfully begun may move
Our fathers hard hearts to a league of love —Enter. Pro.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Wonder not madam at my serious haste,
Your father on my finger spied the ring,
And knowing it, is gone by the known way,
Mark you may hear the doors.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O my sweet friend,
Haste through the hidden way, leave it to me
To excuse it, and retort his jealousy.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Adieu sweet lady,
Hark, hark the last door.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Deceit hath eyes behind, seems blind before —

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: What so sad daughter?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Not sad but solitary.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I see no private passage, and my doors
Rank in their wonted order; prithee daughter
Show me the diamond I gave thee last.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: The ring my lord?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I the ring.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why, would your highness use it?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: She moves a doubt,
I fear there's guile, and I must find it out.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: This is the ring you mean:

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Ay, 'tis the same;
O my own girl, fie my suspicious thoughts
That you should lead me to these jealous fears,
But rings may be alike; my dear, farewell,
Thou shalt not long in this close prison dwell .

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: So Prospero hath promised, and I'll rather
Trust him than you, although you be my father.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: I have observed sir in your troubled looks
Much discontentment, you seem in your appearance
To be some man of high and eminent place
With the great Mantuan Duke.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: What's that to thee?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Not much sir, yet out of a generous spirit
In pilgrim's bread, such as I am professed,
I would some cordial counsels willingly
Bestow upon you, did I know your griefs.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I have in me a natural melancholy;
I have long aimed at greatness, but between me
And that high point two strangers stand opposed;
canst play the skilful surgeon?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Sir I can.
Travel hath taught me much, and though now poor,
Yet in my better days I have conversed
In courts of princes; would you grace me then
But to prefer my service to the Duke,
I would not doubt but to remove those objects
That so offend your eyes; what are those strangers?

sp.speaker: In.
sp.l: The one a young knight that professeth arms:
The other architecture, both are frequent
In the Duke's ear, and I, that in times passed
Had all his bosom and his private thoughts,
Scarce now remember how his chambers hang,
So seldom's my admittance.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Had you so much interest
In his past favours as to make my tongue
Free to his ear I would remove those flatterers,
And plant you in your first deserved grace;
But might I see these gallants —

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Here they come;
The one I take to be a conjurer,
The other his familiar that he works with,
I'll show thee reasons for't.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Observe them sir.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: 'Tis true my lord, this night the Duchess lies in the castle with the lady Valentia, 'tis by the Duke's appointment, because she may be a comfortable kind companion to his daughter; now this night I have cast it so, that we will be merry with them till past midnight.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: But are the ladies pleased it shall be so?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: The bargain's made and sealed firm with a kiss,
I set it fast upon the Duchess lips;
But come let's part till the appointed hour,
We must not be seen too familiar together.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Thou art my better genius, I agree:
I have no good but what I reap from thee.
Mo. Farewell my lord, only take heed of eare-droppers. Ex.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Did you hear that my lord?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Yes, and it strikes cold unto my heart;
Must they this night meet in Valentia's tower)
The devil hath made them picklocks.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Patience sir.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Bid me be frantic, rather rail and curse; at midnight must they meet?
Enough, at that fixed hour I'll rouse the Duke,
And put the court in uproar, with his guard
'Siege round the tower, and take these incubus
Midst their lascivious pastimes.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Hear me sir.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I am deaf to counsel, patience, grace and all,
Till in their midnight rapes these strangers fall.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: O were I now girt with a potent host
Of mine own people, and myself in arms
Engaged unto his rescue, I could then
Assure me of my noble son again;
But I now fear his fall and ominous end,
Whose help 'bove men to heaven I must commend;
Yet I'll not hence, but note what shall ensue,
Heaven hear my prayers, thou art to just men true.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: Madam, this night devote yourself to mirth, whilst your father sleeps secure in his palace, Montecelso hath promised to keep his widow waking; I assure you prince Prospero will be here too instantly.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: He cannot come unlooked for, nor unwished,
So long as their intents are honourable,
So long their welcome is unquestionable.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: Troth madam we have exceedingly forgotten ourselves, we should have had a banquet to have entertained them.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Methinks 'tis better as 'tis without, for the time, that should have been spent in sweetmeats to taste the palate, shall be now spent in sweet discourse to relish the care.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p:
Fie, how long they stay, this hour is as long as three hours: I have observed one thing in lovers hours, the time of
their absence seems hugely too long, and the time when they are present is three to one too short.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And three to one is odds, but you are an old woman.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: That makes me long so much for a husband to make me even; what not yet come, nor yet? if they stay a little longer, I shall go near to swoon thrice before they be ready to enter.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No entrance if you love me.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Yes at the private door —

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Lady.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: Imagine this night to be saint Valentine's day, when every bird chooseth her mate, for that is the season when they couple; I am here.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: And I here.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And I am glad, my lord, that you are here; yet I would be loath, my lord, have my father know that you are so.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: That I am so seated, and you upon my knee.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Upon my knees I beg that it may never come to his care.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Come, what shall's do?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Say what you will my lord, but do nothing I entreat you.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: If we should do nothing, of that must necessary come ill, I'll prove it too; of doing nothing comes idleness, of idleness comes no goodness, of no goodness necessary comes ill: therefore if we do nothing, of necessity we must do ill.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: How well, my lord, you can infer ill; but, my lord, if you should insist much in this argument, it were more to express your oratory than honesty; but my lord, I know your virtues, and the opinion of them hath prepared you a most kind and loving welcome; we have nothing to entertain you but words, and we can feast you with nothing but kisses; now you see your fare, fall to and welcome.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Madam, I could everlastingly feed here, and yet presume never to surfeit, I can but thank you, and now I have given thanks, I'll even make bold to fall to.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You say you could find in your heart to offend my father.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: I madam, so for my offence he would everlastingly confine me to this prison; why smile you lady?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: To think if my father should steal upon you, and find you here, what a cunning picklock he would take you for, he would questionless think you carried a false key about you.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Tush, he hath made a jury of twelve doors already to pass upon my cause, and they have all given my case up not guilty —

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Where's the Duke's guard?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Begird the castle round.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Her windows shine with lights like blazing stars.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: They're in her chamber sure.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Herded you that madam?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: We are betrayed.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: The castle round beset.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: And hark, above I hear the Duke's keys, down the private way, and leave the excuse to us.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Nay, when my lords?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: This way my lord, good night.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Nay, stand not now on trivial compliments,
The duke's at hand.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Farewell, ladies adieu.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Nay, if you love us leave us; madam, how shall we answer this to the Duke?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: Now my apron strings if I had one on, madam take your chair and counterfeit yourself fast asleep, so will I, not a word now if you love me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Thy very words are better to me than a physical potion, for they have cast me into a sound sleep already; see I am fast —

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Soft, make no noise, the chamber's whist and still,
There's not so much air stirring as would make
The trembling aspen shake; ha, fast asleep?
Search round the chamber.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I find no man here.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Here's naught but walls and arras, and two ladies
in depth of sleep.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Let's wake them my lord and question them.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Not for thy head that hast deluded us,
And to this shame and mockery raised the court,
Would I disturb them of a minute's rest;
Thy envy unto such as we have raised
For their desert in court hath stretched itself
Even to our high disturbance.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Hell and the furies,
Am I again deluded?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Fie lord Julio,
To call us in a mockery from our beds!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Here to hunt shadows, sure the fellow dreamt.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Pray my lord wake them, and resolve them how lord Julio hath possessed you.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Pardon me,
They both are charmed in silence, and their senses
Confused in innocent dreams; I oft have heard
That what a man or woman waking thinks,
If they be questioned in their depth of rest
Their genius or their soul will answer for them,
As their affections or their hearts inclined;
Of this I'll make a true and prosperous use,
And sound them how their humours are disposed,
And to my daughter first, lords stand apart,
How sweetly doth my girl become her rest!
How sound are her suspires! Valentia.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: She answers me, now art thou happy Mantua,
For thou shalt sound the utmost of her thoughts;
Whom doth my daughter most affect on earth?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I love none but my father.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: O mine own girl, and wouldst thou not have a husband?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I'll live and die a maid.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: There's no deceit in this, there's no dissembling,
She cannot study for evasive shifts,
I thank heaven I am resolved: now Duchess
your turn is next, I'll try how she likes me,
What thinks the Duchess of the Mantuan Duke?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: As of a fine grave noble gentleman.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Now she speaks her heart, this is plain dealing;
And couldst thou be content to marry him?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: That's my desire.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: And live his noble Duchess.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: I wish no better.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Mine own;
Most sweetly may you sleep, and nightly dream
Of these positions, not for half my dukedom
Would I disturb their quiet; come let's leave them,
Nay pardon me, I'll see the chamber cleared.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Could I be possibly thus mocked?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Nay gentlemen,
I'll be the porter, see I keep the keys
Of these two jewels that I most esteem;
Julio, beware hereafter you incur not
Our wrath by these suggestions of untruths;
Come lords to bed, I counsel you the best,
Goodnight my girls, and sweetly may you rest.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Are they gone wench?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Ay, and so gone that till they have slept soundly, 'tis not possible to fetch them again.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: Now Endymion's fortune upon them, that being once asleep they may not wake again this forty years.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Was it not well apprehended of me to say I loved none but my father?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: And was it not as well seconded of me to say in my sleep I loved none but the Duke? Sure it must be in my sleep if ever I loved him, for yet I could never endure him waking; but what shall's do?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: By my counsel let us even go to bed like loving bedfellows, and see if we can dream of them that in time may become our loving bedfellows.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p:
With all my heart, now the Duke is confident of our affections, we may be the freer in the entertaining of those whom we best affect; come, come, let's leave talking of this
counterfeit sleep, and see if we can take a nap in sadness.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Content, and let all men learn thus much from us, that sleeping or waking 'tis hard to o'erreach a woman. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Yet all things go currant; if the ladies were as nimble in their excuse as we were quick in our passage through the private door, I hope neither the Duke nor any of his court can any way trace us in our proceedings; some lovers would think me a most happy creature to enjoy the love of so beautiful a lady, and for ought I know I may be so; but I have made a vow never to marry a wife, but first to make some perfect and sound trial of her affection towards me; but because there is no woman that loves a man living, but she will infinitely lament him dead, it shall be thought that I have drowned myself, of which I will give the court some assured instance, and afterwards living hereabouts in some odd disguise, I shall truly understand how she takes my death; if in any extremity of grief, I will revive her with as great a surplusage of joy; but if she take it coldly, as a business that little concerns her, I'll leave her to the mercy of him that bids fairest for her; and to my plot, I stay but for some company that may see me throw myself desperately into the river, hear my passion and report it —

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: My work and every thing belonging to the Duke's building being brought to some good pass, I will study how to pass the time, and for the better recreation of my duller spirits take a turn or two here by the river's side to contemplate of the beauty of my mistress; for indeed I am lately fallen in love.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: No fitter man in the world to be the reporter of my death than this coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Upon a morning when I rose to breakfast like a glutton,
I donned my doublet and my hose, and eat two legs of mutton;
Her bonny looks forget I not, nor teeth as white as amber,
Her face did shine like pewter-pot belonging to the chamber;
My lovely mistress I espied as she a milking went a,
But o methought at every stride her smock that she had rent a;
Full pale she looked, for on her head a milkpail was well placed,
Her lips were white, her brows were red, her body was straight-laced;
but shall I now describe her legs, for I durst look no higher,
She went as if she trod on eggs most softly through the mire.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Now to my passion.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: But o a place besides all these above both knees and thighs a,
Which spring, as she looked for fleas, did make my stomach rise a.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Let Jove threat thunder, or bright Juno scold,
Mars threaten arms, armed in Cyclopian steel,
He to my heels clap Boreas brazen wings,
Or mounted on the back of Mercury
With greater terror scale the Olympic heaven,
Then when the giants mustered here on earth,
And darted mountain tops at Jupiter.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: What mad fellow's this? he hath driven me quite out of my meditations, pray heaven I fall not into his fegaries.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: But o my beauteous Duchess, cause of this
My frenzy, lunacy, rage, and despair,
I love thee dear; yet because my fervour
Shall no way cross the noble Mantuan Duke,
I am resolved to die.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Of all the trades that are I love not this dying, poor gentleman, would the Duke knew as much; but if love put a man into these perplexities, I'll take heed how I meddle with it, I'll e'en shake hands with it, and part with it as it came.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Whom do I see, the Duke of Mantua's joy,
She whose bright beauty enamours Jove himself,
And makes him from his crystal throne descend
To 'Bide with this fair mortal, thou art she.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Not I I assure you, I am a man and no woman, if you will not believe me, I have a warrant about me to show.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Come, thou art she, wilt thou dissemble love?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: I am not she, look here I have a beard.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: 'Tis but the periwig fallen from thy temples,
And stays upon thy chin, thou art my Duchess;
But stay, I'll place this border right again,
And set it on thy front where it should stand.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p:
O sir, I'll bring the Duke's own barber that shall take
his oath upon a corporal book, that this is a beard and no periwig; I am he that was overseer of the Duke's work, and not the fair Duchess that you take me for, put on your spectacles, and you will see I am nothing like her.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Then she is lost, and I undone withal,
Therefore I'll strip me to the ivory skin,
And as Leander did lively leap in,
My head beneath yond river I will run,
Neptune spread wide thy arms, for now I come. Exit running.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: O save the man, save the man, now he flounces, now he flounders, yet he swims above water like a walnut shell, yet he sprawls like a naked frog, yet he strives for life, o save the man, save the man; but now, now, now he sinks by degrees, now he is swallowed, now he is choked, this is my comfort, he cannot choose but go with a clean soul to heaven, it will be so washed in the water before he come thither. Again, again, again; now he lies still upon his back and floats along with the tide, and now his soul is in the skies, he doth not offer so much as to strive against the stream, but swims as gently down with the tide as may be; but what a fool was he, that knowing he should go so long a journey by water, and the weather so could too, would leave his clothes behind him? Well, I'll e'en take up his scattered apparel, carry them to the court, and there report what I have heard and seen, the poor gentleman is well onward of his journey by this time, they had need provide him good store of faggots, for he'll be monstrously wet when he comes to his inn.

div.head: Act iv. scene i.
div.stage: Enter Mantua, Florence, Ferrara, Julio, Prospero, and Duchess.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Lady, I understand and good tidings from you.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: From me my lord?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: 'Tis all one madam, you at length are won
Unto a second marriage.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Hath Montecelso then told to the Duke
Of my free grant and yielding to his love?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Sir, I must have you freely reconciled
To the lord Julio that hath put upon you
Such slanderous imputations.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: You my lord
Can much with me, but were't for the reverence
I owe your grace my sword had charactered
My wrong upon his body.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Come, all friends.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: My lord, I yield myself, and here confess
In what high measure I have injured you.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: That's too much to receive injury and make satisfaction too.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: He slandered you most vilely.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Told the Duke
You were safe lodged within Valentia's tower.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Made us to girt the place with the Duke's guard.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: And at the highest of night search all her lodgings
For you and th' architector.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: But who found you?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: None but two sleeping ladies ▪ and they fast
surprised in innocent dreams.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Was this wrong
To be endured?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Where the guilt's confessed
There pardon is soon purchased.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I'll not believe
But there's in this some juggling, some strange feat —

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Room for a bringer of ill news, for one that brings a tale will offend all your noses, and a discourse that will distaste all your ears; who knows this hat? who knows this doublet? who knows this cloak?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: These were lord Montecelso's; why my heart art thou struck cold with fear?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: These were my friends.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: If I mistake not these belonged to him
Whom I preferred to oversee my works,
What news of him?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: You that loved him, out with your eyes, and wipe your handkerchiefs, and as you look upon this cloak provide for a shower of rain.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Speak, what of him?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: He is dead, he is fled, he is not wounded, but he is drowned, he is gone for ever, for he is leapt into the river.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Dead!

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Drowned!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: How came he drowned? speak.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Marry with water, belike it got into his mouth and choked him.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: There's one gone yet.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I mean discourse the cause that urged him to't.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p:
As I was walking by the river's side, musing and meditating on some passions incident to men of my complexion, I spied this gentleman stark staring mad, exclaiming on the beauty of this fair Duchess, saying, that he run mad for her love; but because he would not be false to the Duke his master, that put him in trust, he would rather show himself to be no better than a drowned rat than deceive him, and so very courteously
casts away his hat, very dolefully lays by his cloak, very dissolutely hurls off his doublet, very desperately leaps into the river, and very dangerously gives up the ghost.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: It drives me to amazement,
And I am wrapped in wonder.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: O my fate!
I am of all the most unfortunate;
I'll not outlive him.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Wherefore doth my Duchess
Show in her looks such sad distemperature?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: I am lost, there steals a coldness through my blood,
The icy hand of death plays on my breasts,
And where it toucheth turneth all to earth,
And I am doomed —

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Look to the lady, see she faints.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: How cheer you lady?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Ha, am I called again?
Then like a soul disturbed in her departure,
And kept from rest and downy quietness,
Let me proclaim my anguish.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Patience lady.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: I'll not be patient, give me leave to drown
My soul in brine, and in a flood of tears
Swim to my love.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: The Duchess is distracted.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: I am so, I am desperate, frantic, mad,
Go call yond architector from the deeps,
And he shall build a castle in the air,
Where we will live together 'Midst the clouds
And laugh at these poor mortals here on earth.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: The lady's mad.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: You are deceived, not I;
Cannot a lady weep, mourn, or lament,
Or spend a few tears o'er a funeral hearse
But you will judge her frantic, pray give leave,
Which of you here can hinder me to weep?
I am a woman

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: I am a man.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Women command tears,
Then pray let me bestow some on a friend;
If you will die go hang or drown yourselves,
I'll do the like for you.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Yes, not for me.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Why should I weep for thee if thou didst so,
Or thee, or thee, or any dotard here,
Yet if you please you may go try for me,
He clap at that well-acted tragedy.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: O save the woman, save the woman.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Follow her Julio, see her well attended;
Sure she is planet-struck, or some ill star
Hath in her bosom wrought this mutinous war,

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I'll see well to her safety.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: O my Duchess!

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: These are but women's passions,
And like a tempest, the more violent 'tis
'Twill be the sooner blown o'er.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: So I hope.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Fear not my lord, perhaps she counterfeits
To know how you affect her, if in this
You will compassionate with her, and partake
In this supposed frenzy.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: 'Tis like so,
For if a man may trust a sleeping woman,
She loves me above the world.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: My lord I know it.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Nay, I know it too, I'll never else trust dreams.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: But leaving this, I have a suit unto your grace.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Speak and prevail dear friend.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: There is a Spanish lady my first love,
Who heating of my residence with you,
Is travelled thence to meet me in your court,
I have notice that she shortly will arrive;
My purpose is to feast her in my lodging
So lately built, next to your daughter's tower,
Where if it please you with these lords to grace me,
And taste a homely banquet, I shall say
to you I am engaged every way.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I will not fail thee, nor shall these our friends,
We'll grace the Spanish lady with our presence.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: I have a suit to your grace.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Thy business groom?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: That for the good news I have brought you I may have some guerdon, some remuneration, as they say.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: This thy reward be, since by thy occasion
My Duchess of her best wits is deprived,
Wander for ever like a banished Cain,
Till of her sense she be possessed again
Dare not so near our court. Come lords, let's in
To cheer her sorrows, and her fate lament,
But to the man that can her frenzy cure
We here proclaim whate'er he can demand ▪
If in the compass of our populous land.

sp.speaker: Clown
