sp.p: Banish, what's that? can any man tell me what it means? let me see; banished sure is some strange language, and for any thing I know the meaning of it may be, give him a hundred crowns, or give him two hundred crowns; and banished the court may be come to the court and there you shall receive them; the Duke was not wont to give me such hard words; if he had called me rogue or rascal, I had understood him, I had had him to a hair, but the word banished doth a little stick in my stomach; banished! I will go seek out some wise man or other to tell me what the the word means, and what sum of money, I may demand of the Duke's treasurer; banished —

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Save you sir.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: And you my friend, what are you?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Sir I profess myself to be a wise man.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Then you are the man that I desire to meet, for I was seeking a wise man to tell me the meaning of a strange word.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Unfold thy mind; I shall resolve thee truly ▪
Lie it within the power of humane skill.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p:
Thus stands the case: the Duke entertained a fellow to look to his buildings, and this fellow drowned himself, it was my fate to bring the news to the court, which when the young
Duchess heard, she grew presently as mad as a march hare; now demanding reward for my news, the Duke out of his bounty said, be would banish me the court; now I would fain know what sum of money the word banished signifies.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: It signifies, that if thou dar'st presume
To come within the court gate, thou incurest
The Duke's displeasure, it is present death.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: You will not buy my reward sir, will you?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Then I see thou art a wise man.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: But is the Duchess frantic?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: I'll assure you she's a mad wench.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: And how did the Duke take it?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: O very discontentedly: and he hath proclaimed to him that can cure her of her frenzy to have the next thing he shall ask without exception.

sp.speaker: Mon
sp.l: But art thou sure 'tis true?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: I assure you my friend as true as I am banished.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: That cure I'll undertake, and so prevail,
That I presume my cunning shall not fail.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Now sir I have resolved you of all these doubts, can you tell me how I shall bestow myself now I am banished?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I can, I am a stranger in this city,
And I profess dark arts, physic, and negromancy,
And for a need can conjure; but direct me
Where I may lodge and freely use my art,
I'll entertain thee and supply thy wants
With all things needful.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: As bountiful as wise; I am for you sir so you will teach me wit; I have seen the Duke and his court, but never to my knowledge saw a wiseman afore, you are the first of the name that ever I looked on; but if it be nothing but a lodging you want, trust to me, I can furnish you with that at an hour's warning.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Direct me to the place.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: That I will sir as well as I can,
Be you the wise master, I'll be the wise man.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Attend me then, her choice love I have found,
I made the hurt, and I can cure the wound. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Mantua, Florence, Ferrara, and Julio.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Her fits increase then daily.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: They still grow,
Sometimes her eyes with salt tears overflow;
She fills the house with music, and then wrings
Her ivory hands, she dolefully laments,
At once expressing thousand discontents.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Proclaim to him that can her frenzy cure
The next thing he can ask.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I shall my lord.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: My lord leave these discontents to some further leisure, we are now at the strange knight's lodging to give entertainment to the Spanish lady.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: True, we are his invited guests, and it is not fit that our grievances should any way appear to a stranger.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: You counsel well, behold this is his lodging —
sp.l: And here's the knight himself. Enter Prospero.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Welcome my lord to a poor stranger's lodging,
My beauteous lady and my love's arrived,
Whose grace I first won in a tournament,
Bearing the prize from many knights of Spain;
Please you to grace me at a solemn feast
Which I prepared this day to welcome her,
You shall do much honour.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Knight I will,
And for thy sake respect her to her worth;
How dost thou like thy lodging built so near
This castle where Valentia lies enclosed?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: My lord, 'tis well for prospect and for air,
Wil't please you enter lords, where be my servants. Ex. (Hoboys a banquet.

div.stage: Enter Mantua, Florence, Ferrara, Julio, Prospero.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Is this the place?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: It is my lord; but I must crave your pardon,
We want that order, and that entertainment,
That observation and decorum now
That longs to your estate and sovereignty,
yet our good thoughts above our power are large
And full of zeal.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Come, thou'rt at too much charge.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: May it please your highness to possess your seat,
Homely your viands, but your welcome's great.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: But where's the lady?
She should be mistress of the feast today —

div.stage: Enter Valentia like a Spanish lady.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: She is not far, see yonder where she comes.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: My daughter.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: 'Tis Valentia.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Sure 'tis Valentia in this strange disguise ▪
Or can you once again deceive my eyes?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: My daughter on my life, her eye, her brow,
Her every part; ha, are my eyes my own?
Here hang my keys ▪ the doors fast barred and locked;
Nor is she subtle spirit, composed air,
To creep though keyholes, or to crawl through chinks;
Tush, tush, one lady may be like another,
And my suspect is causeless.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Let me entreat you
To take your seat, my lady's but a stranger,
And unacquainted with th' Italian guise.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Observe her well my lords.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: She hath her blush.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Her lip, her front.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: The right trick of her eye.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: But is it she, is't possible the knight
Would be so bold, she so audacious?
It cannot be; come, now I take my place.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: In this your highness doth your servant grace.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Echa nos de bener dies benediga toda la Compania seias and bien venido.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: What says the lady?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: She calls for wine and bids you welcome all.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: The very touch and accent of her tongue.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Signior yo bono an de buen coracon.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Her meaning.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: She drinks to you with a good heart.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Tell her I pledge gladly.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Doubtless 'tis she, can it be otherwise?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Why spend we time in cups and banquets here,
When fair Valentia must be needs transformed
Unto this stranger-lady.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Still the more
That I observe her I am more confirmed.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: 'Tis she, some devil or witch else.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: When face, and tongue, and each thing proves her mine,
Why should I doubt to challenge her? I'll suddenly
Call on her name, and if she answer to't
Doubtless 'tis she, Valentia — no.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: What means your lordship?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Nothing, nay nothing; see the very ring
Upon her finger, I can sit no longer;
My lords, I must entreat your patience,
I have dropped a jewel as I came along,
And must find it or it will go wrong.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: A jewel lost.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Let's help his grace to seek it.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Pray do my lords.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Some torches there.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Lights for the lords, 'twas dropped sure by the way,
Help him to seek it.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Look well there in the rushes. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Haste through the private door, off with that habit;
If this pass currant we are passed all fear,
Your father's gone in post, why do you stay?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I have the odds, for mine's the nearer way;
Farewell sweet Prospero. Exit.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Seek till your eyes be blind,
You shall lose her though you the jewel find;
How fortune smiles upon our cunning shifts,
They are busy all at work, the Duke himself
Is like a jailor gingling of his keys,
Which serves her as a watchword to uncase;
If now our plot prove, there depends on this
all our succeeding hopes, and future bliss —Ent. Val, above.
Valentia, Valentia.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Here my lord.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: What, at your book already?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Yes sir, to pray
After these tempests for a calmer day.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: The duke's at hand, and seeking how to cross
Our loves hath all his lords left at a loss —Enter man.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Body of me she's here; fool that I am
Her loyalty to mistrust, or his good thoughts,
She being chaste, he honest; how now lady,
What at your book so close?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Books are companions
To them who are compelled to single lives.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Thou art rank 'mongst virgins.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Virgin's would be wives — why come you sir?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Only my girl to see
How well thou farest, thou one day shalt be free;
Fare well, in this my jealousy appears,
And this one fear begets a thousand fears. Exit.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Not without cause, good father, knew you all;
But I must down the next way through the wall. Exit.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: By this she's coming, be thou first fair love,
Or else our stratagem is quite overthrown,
But if't take place, Valentia is mine own;
How will the Duke look when he finds her here ▪
And in his heart condemn his needless fear!
He hath not wit to trace us in our drifts,
True love is cunning and hath thousand shifts —Enter Val.
Valentia.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Prince Prospero.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: And in your habit too, all succeeds happily.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Hark, hark, my father is at hand my lord,
I'll keep my place as if I had not moved,
Whoever ventured fairer where they loved —Enter Mantua

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: How now my lord, what is the jewel found ▪

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: 'T was never lost, I left it in my closet,
where it was safe, 'twas but my jealous fear
And blind mistake, but now those doubts are past,
For where I found it I have locked it fast.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: May it please your grace to sit —

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I have looked my eyes almost blind,
And yet I can no jewel find.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Sure if it had been a diamond, or any stone that had had either lustre or quickness, I should have seen it sparkle.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Lords, you may spare your pains,
The Jewel's found.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Lords, seat yourselves, and grace this stranger's banquet,
And speak what news is in the city rifest,
For you frequent it most.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: They say, my lord, there is a necromancer,
One of rare art and cunning, that can truly
Tell of things lost, one that hath Ephemerides
At his finger's ends; no frenzy, fever, sickness,
But he hath cordials for, so his large bills,
Pasted on every post, speak in his praise.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: And where resides he?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Here in the city Mantua.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Some mountebank fellow.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: It should not seem so,
For he hath much resort, and every mouth
Proclaims his skill.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I will make trial of him,
To know if my love-suit shall well succeed.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I'll try his cunning.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I'll be his client.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: So will I,
And in my deep affairs his best skill try.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I'll prove him in the beauteous Duchess cure,
In which if he prevail his pains shall be
Paid from the best of all his treasury;
We sit too long, stranger, we praise thy bounty,
And if in any suit thou wilt use our love,
Suppose it, craved, granted.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I shall find time my lord.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I cannot he at rest
Till I have once more searched her private chamber to assure and
Of these doubts; strange: farewell,
Only my keys can these sad doubts expel. Exit.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Haste, haste to meet your father in the tower.
Shortly will come the long expected hour. Exit.

div.head: Act v. scene i.
div.stage: A table with a book and papers set out.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: You see I have purchased you a lodging at the house of mine own flesh and blood, otherwise called my father; now sir, if you do not show yourself a master of your art, or your crafts-master, you shall but disgrace yourself, and call the reputation of my father's house in question.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Tush, fear not me, what cannot I perform,
A mask of naked wenches I could bring
To dance strange antiques here, and none but we
To be spectators.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: O brave man, when shall we see this sport?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Dost thou love sweet meats? I have changed ere now,
Against a christning day, a shower of hail
To perfect comfits that have served a feast,
And I can do't again, but tush 'tis nothing.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: O sweet man, here's one that by his art is able to undo all the comfet-makers in Christendom,

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: What meat dost thou love best?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p:
I love many meats well, and indeed scarce any comes
amiss, if it be come in his right likeness, when I have a stomach I can eat capon and rabbit, but above all meats, not to dissemble, I love a good piece of roasted beef.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I'll tell thee what once I did in Germany.
There was a hill lay just against the sun,
I by my art changed it to perfect beef ▪
Which the violent heat of the sun roasted as
Perfectly as any sea coal fire, and still as it
Was enough the country people came with their
Sharp knives and cut it off in slices.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: O that my journey had lain over that hill.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Now sir a brook ran by of clear water,
And that I turned to perfect vinegar
For sauce to that roast-beef, and the small sand
Was changed to perfect pepper; now sir, it
Was but bringing stead along with them and slicing away
A piece of the hill, and sitting down by the river's side,
And there was as good rost beef, vinegar, and pepper
As any man in Mantua could desire to eat.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: This cunning man hath a trade would set any man's teeth a watering that hath but a stomach —Enter Prospero.
But soft, here come strangers.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: If the wise man be as cunning as rumour reports him,
I'll know what shall betide me in my love-affairs;
This, I this, by my directions should be the house.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: My cousin the prince, excellent, I'll put him
Into a pitiful perplexity ere we part.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Now will I try whether this fellow have any cunning or no, thou learned man of Mantua heaven save thee.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Thou worthy gentleman of Verona, I thank thee,
Nay, I have given 't you, pick out the meaning of that.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: He knows me to be of Verona.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Ay, and an enemy to the Duke of Mantua,

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: You wrong me sir, I love the Duke.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Ay, and his daughter too, pray do you not?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: A rare admirable fellow, he knows all, I must colloque with him, or he'll reveal all my secrets to the Duke.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p:
Nay, herein, most learned, I must needs say you err;
and though I will not say your devil is a liar, because I am altogether unacquainted with him, yet in this I must needs tell you he is in the wrong, for this gentleman is a true Trojan, a knight errant, and one that hath fought at the tomb of adventures.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Indeed I am a stranger.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Indeed you are a dissembler.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: My name's Antonio.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Otherwise called prince Prospero.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: The rarest fellow in Christendom; upon my life he knows my very thoughts, my meditations.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Come hither you, you that can gull the Duke,
Make private doors into his daughter's tower ▪
And whilst your noble father, good old man,
Thinks you abroad in travel to see fashions,
You loiter here about a lady's love.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: O wonderful, I never heard the like ▪

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Now where's the ring the Duke spied on your finger?
When was the merry meeting with your friend
And the two ladies when they talked asleep,
And by that sudden shift deceived the Duke?
Where's the strange Spanish lady? where's the banquet
To which you did invite him?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: He knows all, all by this light,
There's nothing left unknown.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Here's no roguery, here's no knavery, here's no villainy, and all confessed too, I'll even, like a good subject, make all this acquainted to the Duke.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Sweet conjurer, good Mephastophilis ,
I'll give thee here a hundred ducats straight
But keep my counsel.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: But if the wiseman will, the fool will not; nay, and there be such knaveries in hand, you had better never have let them come to my ear, the Duke shall know all, all by this hand, nay, that's most certain — trust to it.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Stay sirrah, or I'll bring you back with a whirlwind.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Not I most learned, you shall pardon me, I'll be no traitor for no man's pleasure.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Prithee come back.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: No such matter, have you such vagaries, I'll tell the Duke.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: You door-maker.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: How most wise?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: The Duke shall know of making of that door
By which the prince had free way to the lady,
You were his overseer.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: No more, sweet doctor Faustus, no more.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Sirrah, you had better been a door keeper than a door-maker.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Then I had better be a thief than a knave, silence noble scholar, and I am at thy service.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Well sirrah, keep his counsel and I'll keep yours, and whilst I speak a few words with this stranger, do thou watch there, and look steadfastly at the kitchen window, for about dinner time there will fly in capons, pigeons, pigs, geese, larks, chickens all ready roasted, with every one a knife at his girdle to cut himself up, do but thou watch and bring me word when they come flying in and call me; we'll to dinner.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: O rare, ready roasted! I would I were a wise man too, as I shall never be whilst I live; it is nothing but spreading a cloth, laying trenchers, setting a salt, providing of bread, and making platters and sauce ready, and your roast-meat will come as duly every one flying to his own dish and sauce as crows in the evening fly to their own nests; I'll get him to tile our house with biscuits, to pave the kitchen with custards, to make our lo●e-walls of gingerbread, and turn our cheese-trenchers into wafer-cakes; I'll watch, but if I bring him word till I have filled my belly, may my girdle break.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Montecelso turned a wise man!

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: I know that's more than ever thou didst look for at my hands.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Beshrew thee coz, thou hast put me into two pitiful plunges, first thy death, next for this needless fear.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Not yet!

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I thought as surely thou hadst been in heaven
As I know this is earth: introth mad coz,
And hast thou gone beyond me?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Now I hope: no, that was a crow that flew over our house.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Be confident for I have cast a plot.
How thou shalt steal away thy love to church,
And make her father with his own free hand
Give her to thee in marriage; more than this,
Put strange disgraces on thy opposites
And such as are thy rivals; wouldst thou think
Me a perfect wise man to contrive this well?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: More wise than I first knew thee.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: For this time part, early tomorrow morning
Convey Valentia through the private door
Suited as at the banquet; next invite
The Mantuan Duke to grace your nuptials
In saint Lauretta's chapel; what remains
Shall all be mine.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: My dearest friend adieu,
No cunning head had e'er a heart so true. Exit. — knock.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Hark, some one knocks.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Most prudent.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Leave staring to the kitch till anon,
And let me in these gallants.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Beshrew their hearts for me, belike they heard what good cheer was flying towards our house, and now like bold guests they are come to bid themselves to dinner; I will let them in, though I could wish them choked for their pains —

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Who takes his turn first?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: That will I so please you.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I know them all, their business, their affairs,
And I shall fit them finely; grave old man,
My choicest welcome I bestow on you,
And welcome lords to all, but first you:
I know my lord of Florence you affect
The amorous lady fair Valentia.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: O marvelous!

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: But you the frantic Duchess.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Possible.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Come, come, I know the inmost of your thoughts,
Then to be brief and cut off circumstance,
hark you my lord of Florence, do but this,
And I'll assure you fair Valentia's love,
Tomorrow morning must the stranger knight
In saint Lauretta's chapel wed his love,
The Spanish lady, given him by the Duke,
Whilst they are busied watch the new-built tower,
In which by art I will contrive a door,
Which you shall find wide open.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: O rare man!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Through which pass freely; now to blind suspicion,
Because you may not be descried or known,
Wear some disguise, this paper shall direct you.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Thou most ingenious artist, take this gold,
The happy earnest of my future love. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Enough my lord, now wait upon my skill;
And now to you, I know you love the Duchess,
But she is changed by sickness; yet my lord
If you will marry fair Valentia,
Who for your love disdains the florentine,
I'll set you down a course to compass it.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Either will serve my turn, I'm not so curious
To thy my fancy to one woman's face.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Know, through my spirits help, I have digged a door
Quite through the turret's door, which wall leads straight
Unto the lady's chamber, take this note,
This paper shall direct you.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: There's gold for paper.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Adieu.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: My turn is next;
I am a stranger to thee, learned friend,
Nor dost thou know my business.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: No lord Julio.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Julio I'm called indeed.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: And love that lady
Whom these two princes tenderly affect.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Thou'rt something near me.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I'll come nearer yet,
To the two strangers I could tell your hate,
th'one drowned, tother guardian of the tower,
But my art's no accuser.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Noble scholar,
Let this gold bribe thy art to secrecy,
And teach me how I may prevent their plots,
Gain the Duke's grace, and fair Valentia's love.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: This paper shall do all, peruse it then,
And let it be your tutor, so now leave me.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: With all my art I'll prove thy magic skill,
And to the utmost what thou plot'st fulfil,Exit.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Adieu; you sirrah.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Most judicious.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Follow them with speed,
Watch them, and when thou seest them near the tower,
Run to the Duke and call his armed guard
To apprehend these miners that have digged
Unlawful passage through his high-built tower,
See them well beaten, and after come to me,
And I will teach thee this rare negromancy.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Fear not, master doctor, first I'll play my part,
And after come to you to learn your art.Exit.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Now sir to you.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: And what to me sir? think not with your tricks
To draw me in opinion you are wise.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Were not your grace a man I reverence.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: My grace, what grace? you'd gull me would you not?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Nor can you gull me most excellent lord,
You are Verona's Duke; nay, never start,
For to your care my tongue's close as your heart;
I know that Mantua loves you not, yet know
Your son serves Mantua as a friendly foe.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Pardon me sir, I now approve your cunning,
Conceal my being, and expect reward —
But see the Duke.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: What liberal reprover, I perceive
You find some matter in this man of note.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Matter indeed my lord, this is a man
exceeding many other private men,
That are indeed but shadows, counterfeits,
This man hath natural gifts joined with his art.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: We like your praise, and will ourself applaud
His excellence, if by his grounded skill
He can give case to this fair Duchess grief.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: What mortals can attempt I'll undertake;
This is the lady, and I know her grief
Arises from a sullen melancholy;
She has lost some friend, the sorrow of whose death
Hath turned her sanguine streams of blood to black.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Black, lost, gone, sunk, fled, adieu, farewell,
The waves have quite undone poor Lucibell.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Tush, I can cure this madness presently.

sp.speaker: Man
sp.l: How learned friend? restore her to her senses,
And the next thing that thou demandest is thine.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I know the perfect temper of her grief,
Which that you may perceive I'll cure with art;
I will raise up the ghost of him she loved,
So like in all things you yourselves shall swear
It is the man.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Shall he appear to us?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Here to you all, but stir not, move no foot,
Take heed you do not question him too far,
But only hear and see, and stand aloof.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: But will he not affright us?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Not a jot;
Look to the lady, I'll about my art,
And send the architector presently,Exit.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Well, if I see him I will chide him so,
That he shall never drown himself again.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Is't possible this can be done by art?
Or means he to delude us?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: So it seems, for I shall ne'er more see my love again.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Sweet lady be content.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: You see I am.
The sound may give whole counsel to the sick,
Away, your counsel does increase my pain,
and I shall ne'er more see my love again —

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: He's come already.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Lord how like he is!
Would you not swear it were the very man;
An admirable artist I see he wafts the lady.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: O thou dear soul of my sweet love deceased,
I'll follow thee.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Stir not, it is the devil.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Spirit or fiend, his amorous shape so charms,
Did he grasp hell I'd fly into his arms. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: The devil hath born her hence, follow and rescue her.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Not I my lord, your grace shall pardon me.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: O what black trespass hath she done 'gainst heaven
That she should thus be hurried quick to hell;
Now is she hopeless, past recovery;
I'll hang that conjurer.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Condemn him not before you see the event.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: What can the event be but her utter loss?
O my fair Duchess, if thou perish thus,
I'll make that base enchanter curse this day,
For thy lost blood his traitorous head shall pay —

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: How cheers my lord, did you behold the ghost?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: We saw the devil, but speak, where's the Duchess?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Safe in my chamber, where before tomorrow,
Your grace shall see her perfectly recovered,
Doubt not my art; but there remains, my lord,
For you a further business, the strange knight
Expects the Spanish lady from your hand
In saint Lauretta's chapel, whither I promise
To bring your lady perfectly recovered.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: See this done,
And the next thing that thou demandest is thine.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I shall make bold, my lord, to claim your promise.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Claim it and take it.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: You'll trust her in my chamber for this night,
For I must physic her.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Do what thou pleasest, it highly shall content me;
Come, let's return to court, and there attend
Of our precedent fears a fortunate end. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Thou hast no part in that fair fortunate end,
It belongs to me, and to my noble friend: madam —

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: O my dear love how could you so delude
A lady that with such entire affection
And zealous love admired and honoured you!

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Of that no more; the Duke for this great cure
Hath promised me what I shall next demand,
I have a boon to ask, I have set on foot
Many strange plots which must their full effect
Receive this night, the prince is to espouse
The fair Valentia by the Duke's free gift,
Florence, Ferrara, and lord Julio,
His rivals, are about their several tasks;
Something there remains for me, amongst the rest,
And you to act out of these confusions,
We must devise our fortunes to secure,
And save that love that is so chaste and pure. Exeunt. Hoboys.

div.stage: Enter at one door a Bishop, Mantua, and Verona, fetch Prospero and Valentia, Mantua makes some strange pauses, viewing the lady exactly, at length (Recalling his hand once or twice) troath-plights them, and so march over to the church.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: In this disguise who can know Julio now.
Or guess the purpose that I have in hand?
This paper tells me I shall find a door
Left open to Valentia's amorous bed: here I'll wait
The happy end of my auspicious fate —

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: So I am fitted so un willingly
That I scarce know myself; yet as this paper
Gives me directions may I find the door
Left open to me, I desire no more —

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: A carpenter I should be, would this apron
And rule bring me to rule in Mantua
By marriage of the fair Valentia,
I should applaud my fortunes, and commend
The wise man's art; this can imperious love,Ent. Clo. and guard.
Whose power hath oft transhaped the gods above.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: You shall be transhaped I'll warrant you, we'll teach you to take upon you other men's trades before you be free of their companies; if your rule at your back will not rule you, we will; stand close gentlemen, and though we find them broad awake, let's see if we can take them napping.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: The door, according to to the wiseman's words,
I find wide open, I'll enter.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Why pause I being so near?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I'll enter instantly, but soft, I am prevented.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Company, now must I counterfeit to work.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: To shun discovery,
I'll see how I can play the carpenter.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Now to my masonry.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Would I were ten leagues off.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Upon them gentlemen, upon them, these be the underminers I told you of, up with your pole-axes and down with them, see they have broken open a door already, they shall be arraigned of burglary.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Hold, hold, and hear us.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Bombast them gentlemen, currifeige them bravely, hear them after; pelt the mason with stones, hammer the smith, and overrule the carpenter, come, away with 'em. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: My son is married to the Mantuan Princess,
A lady of that presence and opinion,
That it offends me not; but to prevent
Any offence that may be done to him,
Or injury to me, I have at hand
A royal army under cosmos charge,
Our trusty and approved counsellor,
To offer war or peace — the duke's at hand. Exit. Flourish.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: How naked is our train, that of our courtiers,
So few attend this high solemnity?
Where's Florence? where's Ferrara? where's lord Julio?
That have not seen us given away this
Daughter I fear, for so my eye persuades;
Had I not in these keys such confidence,
And in the strength of my large edifice,
I should not doubt to swear, but these I'll trust,
When servants fail, keys and stonewalls prove just.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Thrice worthy sir, you have given me such a gift,
Should you impart you dukedoms large revenue
It could not equalled; now your hand is past,
Which both your word and church-rights have made fast.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: 'Twere best that I return to see all safe ▪
And next inquire how my fair Duchess fares.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Fear not my lord, you have committed her
To his protection that undoubtedly
Will see to her recovery.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: So we hope.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Restore her to her senses and true feeling.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: We doubt it not.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: And apt her thoughts for love.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: That's all we covet.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I have understood
By those that know him, so much he'll make good.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Then are we truly happy —

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Room for one good subject that brings three bad subjects to answer burglary before your grace: see here my lord, here are three fellows that have good faces and are ashamed to show 'em, they seem to be sound men, yet see if they do not strive to look scurvily?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: What men are these? or how have they offended?
Why do they turn their heads thus and look downwards?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: As if they had stolen a pudding.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: These faces I should know, my lord of Florence,
Ferrara's marquess, and lord Julio;
is this the cost you have so liberally
Bestowed to grace our feast? my bride and I
Are much bound to you

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: These the men, perhaps they have some mask,
If so, let's see't.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Compel me not to answer.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Give me leave
To blush and be ashamed.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Hell take the conjurer.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: My lords, what means this antique ▪ if you have
Some sport to show us ▪ pray my lords let's have't.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: So, so.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: How well this suit becomes you! troth my lord,
Might I advise you, I would still go thus;
Acquaint me with your tailor.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Is this the newest fashion?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Would I were in the Indies
Rather than here.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: But tell me sirrah, what means this show?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Call you these lords! no, they are loons, they look more like prentices than princes; these are they that have beleaguered your new tower, and digged a hole through the wall, that an ox or an ass, 'Bless us, as big as yourself may creep through; there's a door made into your daughter's tower where she was kept, and the door being left open she is flown away: Valantia is gone, she is gone, and these are they that had their hands in the business.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Valentia gone, and by their practice lost!

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: By theirs; when they were boring at the hole we took them at it with their tools out, we took them in the manner before they could put up, and here we have brought them to answer before your grace, that you may freely punish their weakness that would offer to go to your walls.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: These injuries severely we'll revenge,
But most on thee false Julio, for her loss
Thy head shall pay.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Pox of the conjurer I say still.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Speak, where's Valentia, can you tell me?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Then for her loss your forfeit lives shall go;
Who can advise me best where I may find
Her I most loved, and hath proved most unkind.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Might I advise your grace, I would have you should do as archers do, that when they have lost an arrow, shoot another after it; so, my lord, if you have ever another lady or mistress about the court, shoot her after your daughter, that you may either find one, or lose both.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Good counsel.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: To him that can reduce her to her tower,
Or put me in possession of her hand,
What grace our power or dukedom can command
Shall all be his.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I take you at your word, see here my lord.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: This, this is the Spanish lady.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: She that spoke
In Spanish once is forced to change her tongue,
Pardon dear father.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Ha! am I then o'erreached? is't possible
For all my cost, charge, care, and diligence
A wenches wit outgo me? could her subtlety
Make way through that which not an army could?
What should I say?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Those creatures that wear smock's
Will where they love pierce stonewalls, creep through locks;
Why thus you see, as well as we, a great man may be gulled,
Woodcocks are meat, but not to eat until that they be pulled. Ex.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: That private door, my lord, I now perceive
Was made by him.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: My lord, remember you
The ring you spied upon his finger once,
Then think upon the door.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: You made us toss the rushes
And seek the jewel, did you? Speak, what art thou
That thus hast gulled the Duke?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I am a prince,
And every way thy equal.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I would to heaven it were no worse.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: He is no less my lord, receive him then to grace.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Of whence?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Verona.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Mine enemy.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Was't not a friendly part
To lodge your only child so near my heart?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My lord, remember he once saved your life,
And even for that deserves me for his wife.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Now as a friend a friendly league I crave,
Take not away what you so freely gave.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I will pause upon't, although it be passed help,
And see what we may punish, what forgive;
But now my only comfort is stored up
In the fair Duchess, if she gain her health —Ent. Dutch. and Mont.
And here she comes, I cannot choose but fear
So long as I behold you ghost so near.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: That conjurer
Is a rare artist that can raise a shadow
So like unto the substance.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Fair Duchess, art thou recovered, speak?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Thank heaven I am.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: 'Tis well done to have heaven still in thy thoughts
Being so near a fiend, come from that devil.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Fear not my lord, I am so armed with faith,
And love withal, he hath no power to hurt me.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Art thou well?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Yes my lord, I am well.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Come from him, but art thou very well?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Very well my lord I thank you.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Perfectly well?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: So well you cannot wish me better.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Come hither then.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: I was of late but ill,
Then give me leave, my lord, to keep myself
Well while I am well.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: That's with me my lord.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Can the ghost speak too.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Speak, and talk, and walk,
Embrace and kiss.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I love no kissing ghosts.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Believe me, that magician was a man
Of rare experience, and deserves great praise.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Did he not say before what he should do,
That ghost doth act his part exceedingly.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I say come from him, he's a spirit.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: I do not love to do any thing but with a spirit.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: He came out of hot hell.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: He'll make the warmer bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Further than you have been, be not deceived my lord.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: That's far enough already.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I am the man I seem, no architector,
But cousin to that noble gentleman
Prince Prospero, of the Duke Verona's court,
That for this Duchess love have thrust myself
Into this imminent danger, as the prince
Hath done the like for his Valentia;
You promised me if I could cure this lady,
The next thing I demanded, her I crave,
Whom if I truly merit let me have.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I have been gulled on all sides, nor will I
Put up these injurious wrongs, you both shall die —Ent. Jul.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: To arms, to arms my lord, for I descry
A potent army marching before our walls,
And by their colours flying they should be of Verona.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Be they from whence they will we'll parley them;
Admit their general to an interviewFlourish.
To know their cause of arms —Enter Verona.
Our Clinick turned a soldier I

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Noble father I crave your pardon.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I the like my lord.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Stand on our party then whilst I debate
Our purpose with this Duke; these arms we levied
With no intent of wrong to Mantua,
But to secure our son, and this his friend,
We do protest it is no work of ours
that he is married, neither did we wish't ▪
But since by heaven and fate they are united,
We rather wish they may their loves enjoy,
Than what heaven seems to applaud we should destroy.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: To plead in arms is best way to prevail,
Where still the weakest must yield; since our own blood
Hath had an equal share in this our wrong,
Why should we envy strangers, we will strive
From the world's eye to hide this ominous scar;
Heaven offers peace, why should we threaten war?
Each where they love join hands.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Our hearts.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: A sweet conclusion.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: And now madam I'll make you amends for mocking you.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Great men are sometimes gulled, but that's not common,
You have done more, for you have gulled a woman.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Your son, Verona, and his friend hath much
Outstriped us by their wit, but the best is
We are not gulled alone,
You see your greatness is no privilege
From those that have quick brains, but now all friends;
Verona we embrace, and thus atone
All our dissensions; marriage shall conclude
What arms hath menaced; our united dukedoms
Since by this happy fate they are agreed,
We'll strive which most in bounty shall exceed.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
